S1.T1.caption: Table 1: TotalCom complexity of linearly converging algorithm using Local Training (LT), Communication Compression (CC), or both. The 𝒪~~𝒪\widetilde{\mathcal{O}} notation hides the log⁡(ϵ−1)superscriptitalic-ϵ1\log(\epsilon^{-1}) factor. We note that some of the referenced methods incorporate features of practical interest like data sampling, i.e. replacing the exact local gradient calls by stochastic estimates, or partial participation. They are irrelevant for our purpose, since they can only worsen the communication complexity, which is the object of our study.
S1.T1.footnotes: (a)𝑎(a) using independent rand-1 compressors, for instance. Note that 𝒪​(d​κ+d)𝒪𝑑𝜅𝑑\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{d}\sqrt{\kappa}+d) is better than 𝒪​(κ+d)𝒪𝜅𝑑\mathcal{O}(\kappa+d) and 𝒪​(d​κn+d)𝒪𝑑𝜅𝑛𝑑\mathcal{O}(d\frac{\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+d) is better than 𝒪​(dn​κ+d)𝒪𝑑𝑛𝜅𝑑\mathcal{O}(\frac{d}{n}\kappa+d), so that CompressedScaffnew has a better complexity than DIANA.       (b)𝑏(b) using top-k𝑘k compressors with any k𝑘k, for instance.
references:
This double acceleration is all the more remarkable, given that it is very challenging to combine LT and CC. In the strongly convex and heterogeneous case considered here, the methods Qsparse-local-SGD (Basu et al.,, 2020) and FedPAQ (Reisizadeh et al.,, 2020) do not converge linearly. The only linearly converging LT + CC algorithm we are aware of is FedCOMGATE (Haddadpour et al.,, 2021). But its rate is 𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}, which does not show any acceleration. By contrast, our algorithm is the first, to the best of our knowledge, to exhibit a doubly-accelerated linear rate, by leveraging LT and CC.
Random reshuffling, which can be seen as a kind of LT, has been combined with CC in Sadiev et al., (2022).
The TotalCom complexity of the various algorithms is reported in Table 1.

We have reported in Table 1 the TotalCom complexity for several algorithms, and to the best of our knowledge, CompressedScaffnew improves upon all known algorithms, which use either LT or CC on top of GD.
